claim: Colleges sell degrees rather than providing instruction
text: Colleges sell degrees rather than providing instruction
quote: Colleges Sell Degrees, not Instruction

claim: Enrollment rates matter more than retention and graduation rates for universities
text: Enrollment rates matter more than retention and graduation rates for universities
quote: Enrollment-rates Matter: Retention- and Graduation-rates Don't

claim: Universities have a distinctive business model that differs from open-market companies
text: Universities have a distinctive business model that differs from open-market companies
quote: Universities: Their Distinctive Business-model

claim: Open-market companies operate differently from universities
text: Open-market companies operate differently from universities
quote: Open-market Companies (OMC's): How they Differ from Universities

claim: There is a question about whether graduation and retention rates actually matter
text: There is a question about whether graduation and retention rates actually matter
quote: Do Graduation- and Retention-rates Matter?

claim: There is a paradox regarding macroeconomic efficiency in higher education
text: There is a paradox regarding macroeconomic efficiency in higher education
quote: The Paradox of Macroeconomic Efficiency

claim: Dropping out is not necessarily indicative of failure
text: Dropping out is not necessarily indicative of failure
quote: When in Doubt, Drop Out: Dispelling the Myth that Only Losers Drop Out

claim: Knowledge management cannot assist universities in their current form
text: Knowledge management cannot assist universities in their current form
quote: Why Knowledge-management Cannot be of Assistance to Universities

claim: Revenue can be maximized by optimizing education
text: Revenue can be maximized by optimizing education
quote: How to Maximize Revenue by Optimizing Education

claim: Knowledge management functions as a preventative measure
text: Knowledge management functions as a preventative measure
quote: KM as Preventative Measure

claim: Knowledge management applies differently to organizations that sell results versus services
text: Knowledge management applies differently to organizations that sell results versus services
quote: KM in Relation to Organizations that Sell Results

claim: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management
text: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management
quote: Service-organizations Depend on Poor KM

claim: Knowledge management is impossible without performance-dependent employment and pay
text: Knowledge management is impossible without performance-dependent employment and pay
quote: KM Impossible Unless Employment and Pay are Performance-dependent

claim: Knowledge management requires financial transparency
text: Knowledge management requires financial transparency
quote: No KM without Financial Transparency

claim: Expense padding is related to knowledge management issues
text: Expense padding is related to knowledge management issues
quote: Expense-padding in Relation to KM

claim: Education must be digitized whenever possible
text: Education must be digitized whenever possible
quote: Education Must be Digitized Whenever Possible

claim: DMO represents a new and better kind of university
text: DMO represents a new and better kind of university
quote: DMO: A New and Better Kind of University

claim: All accreditations should be examination-based
text: All accreditations should be examination-based
quote: All Accreditations Examination-based

claim: DMO can transform non-STEM students into STEM students
text: DMO can transform non-STEM students into STEM students
quote: How DMO Turns Non-STEM Students into STEM Students

claim: Emphasis should be placed on instruction rather than selection
text: Emphasis should be placed on instruction rather than selection
quote: Emphasis on Instruction as Opposed to Selection

claim: DMO should offer more degree levels than traditional universities
text: DMO should offer more degree levels than traditional universities
quote: More Degree-levels at DMO

claim: Instructors should never function as gatekeepers
text: Instructors should never function as gatekeepers
quote: Instructors Never to Function as Gatekeepers

claim: Payments should go directly from students to instructors
text: Payments should go directly from students to instructors
quote: Payments to Go Straight from Student to Instructor

claim: There should be an inverted payment pyramid structure
text: There should be an inverted payment pyramid structure
quote: The Inverted Payment Pyramid

claim: DMO must satisfy 25 specific desiderata
text: DMO must satisfy 25 specific desiderata
quote: 25 Desiderata that DMO Must Satisfy

claim: The work addresses the economics of higher education in the contemporary era
text: The work addresses the economics of higher education in the contemporary era
quote: The Economics of Higher Education in the 21st Century

claim: There are specific individuals who sound alarms about knowledge management
text: There are specific individuals who sound alarms about knowledge management
quote: Who Exactly Sounds the KM-alarm?

claim: Knowledge management relates differently to service organizations
text: Knowledge management relates differently to service organizations
quote: KM in Relation to Organizations that Sell Services

claim: There is a question about how useful students actually want their education to be
text: There is a question about how useful students actually want their education to be
quote: How Useful Do Students Really Want Their Educations To Be?

claim: Universities are not threatened by low retention and graduation rates because they sell degrees, not instruction
text: Universities are not threatened by low retention and graduation rates because they sell degrees, not instruction
quote: universities are in no way threatened by low retention-rates and graduation-rates

claim: Universities cannot improve educational quality without endangering their existence
text: Universities cannot improve educational quality without endangering their existence
quote: universities cannot significantly improve or otherwise alter the quality of their educational services without imperiling their very existences

claim: Retention rate is the percentage of students who stay after the first year
text: Retention rate is the percentage of students who stay after the first year
quote: A university's retention rate is the percentage of students who stay after the first year

claim: Graduation rate is the percentage of students who graduate within six years of enrollment
text: Graduation rate is the percentage of students who graduate within six years of enrollment
quote: A university's graduation rate is the percentage of students who graduate within six years of enrollment

claim: Universities have financial reasons to want high retention but not necessarily high graduation rates
text: Universities have financial reasons to want high retention but not necessarily high graduation rates
quote: From a financial perspective, a university has relatively cogent reasons to want a high retention rate: when a student doesn't enroll for a second year, that university loses business, and it doesn't when he does. A university has less strong reasons to want a high graduation rate. If a student comes back year after year and never graduates, the university makes more money than it does if he graduates

claim: Great Basin College has extremely low rates but remains financially stable
text: Great Basin College has extremely low rates but remains financially stable
quote: Great Basin College in Nevada has a retention rate of 4% and a graduation rate of 0%, but it is not in financial trouble

claim: Universities would lose their customer base if they made changes to improve retention
text: Universities would lose their customer base if they made changes to improve retention
quote: If a university made the systemic changes to itself necessary to improve retention rates, it would lose most of its existing customer-base

claim: Universities sell degrees, not instruction or services
text: Universities sell degrees, not instruction or services
quote: Universities pay people for degrees. That is what universities sell, and that is what people pay them for; and with relatively minor qualifications, that is all that people pay them for

claim: The fundamental difference between universities and open market companies is what they sell
text: The fundamental difference between universities and open market companies is what they sell
quote: There is one very important difference between universities and OMC's. OMC's sell products and services. That is what people pay them for. That is all they pay them for. That is not what people pay universities for

claim: A hypothetical William & Mary that improved instruction but stopped giving degrees would see enrollment plummet
text: A hypothetical William & Mary that improved instruction but stopped giving degrees would see enrollment plummet
quote: William & Mary magically improves the quality of its instruction 100% and it cuts its tuition in half: but it stops issuing degrees. So whatever it is that one can currently learn at William & Mary about physics, psychology or any other subject, one can now learn twice as well for half as much money. But one cannot get a degree in that subject from William & Mary. Under these circumstances, William & Mary's enrollment rate would plummet, possibly to zero

claim: Degrees function as necessary credentials for professional opportunities regardless of actual learning
text: Degrees function as necessary credentials for professional opportunities regardless of actual learning
quote: Max is a mathematical genius who has completely mastered his discipline... But he doesn't have a college degree, and he has never attended college. What can Max do professionally? He cannot be a professor. He cannot publish in academic journals. He cannot be a high-school teacher

claim: College degrees provide access to white-collar employment regardless of intelligence or competence
text: College degrees provide access to white-collar employment regardless of intelligence or competence
quote: Jane is a person of average or marginally above intelligence who has a degree in psychology. Tammy is exactly as intelligent as Jane, both psychologically and otherwise, but does not have a college degree. For Jane, the possibilities are endless... But what about Tammy? What are her options? She cannot become a licensed therapist. She cannot work for a corporation, except in a menial capacity

claim: College attendance is rational even when outcomes are uncertain because degrees provide options
text: College attendance is rational even when outcomes are uncertain because degrees provide options
quote: People with degrees have options, and people without degrees don't. People with useful degrees from high-prestige institutions have many very good options; people with useless degrees from low prestige institutions have fewer options and they are not as good—but they are still good in absolute terms, and they are still plentiful. People without degrees do not have options

claim: Students don't want high-quality demanding instruction since they're paying for degrees
text: Students don't want high-quality demanding instruction since they're paying for degrees
quote: since they are paying for degrees, they want to have to jump through as few hoops as possible to get those degrees

claim: Enrollment rates matter for university finances, not retention or graduation rates
text: Enrollment rates matter for university finances, not retention or graduation rates
quote: it isn't retention rates that matter: it is enrollment rates. If enough people enroll, then the university is financially ok

claim: Universities with extremely low retention rates can operate profitably by targeting marginal students
text: Universities with extremely low retention rates can operate profitably by targeting marginal students
quote: Suppose that a university's target-customer is somebody who desperately wants a college degree but, in terms of finances or intellect, is just on the cusp on of being able to complete a college degree. It may well that for every hundred such people who enroll, only four are able to make it to the second year

claim: Universities have distinctive business models that prevent rapid organizational change
text: Universities have distinctive business models that prevent rapid organizational change
quote: An OMC can turn on a dime. It can replace its entire labor force. It can start making new products. It can fire its CEO... But universities sell degrees—nothing else

claim: Universities depend on providing instruction that is just good enough to maintain degree prestige
text: Universities depend on providing instruction that is just good enough to maintain degree prestige
quote: the ideal situation for a university is when its degrees have prestige and as few people as possible are actually giving them that prestige

claim: Most students want well-paid jobs with poorly defined functions rather than useful employment
text: Most students want well-paid jobs with poorly defined functions rather than useful employment
quote: What most college students want, at least if their eventual careers are any indication, is to be relatively useless and employed

claim: Advanced economies can support large populations of unproductive workers
text: Advanced economies can support large populations of unproductive workers
quote: In economies of scale, there is enormous division of labor, and only a small percent of the population actually has to produce. The more advanced an economy is, the greater the percentage of people in it who can be useless

claim: College dropouts often make rational decisions based on cost-benefit analysis
text: College dropouts often make rational decisions based on cost-benefit analysis
quote: When people drop out, it is usually (not always) because it isn't worth it for them to stay

claim: Knowledge management cannot help universities because they depend on poor internal communications
text: Knowledge management cannot help universities because they depend on poor internal communications
quote: Unlike OMC's, universities actually depend on poor internal communications

claim: Knowledge Management explains how institutions must organize to optimize information flow
text: Knowledge Management explains how institutions must organize to optimize information flow
quote: KM explains how institutions must be organized if knowledge-exchanges that must occur are to occur

claim: University departments remain isolated to protect professors from scrutiny
text: University departments remain isolated to protect professors from scrutiny
quote: if a philosophy professor teamed up with an economics professor, that philosophy professor could (and probably would) be called out economics students who were not under his thumb

claim: The solution is to create new educational institutions rather than reform existing universities
text: The solution is to create new educational institutions rather than reform existing universities
quote: if one wants to improve education and to make money doing so, there is at the current an enormous opportunity. Right now is the perfect time to make education affordable, fast, effective, and also (for the owner of the educational service in question) extremely lucrative

claim: DMO will be a results-based online university that sells competence rather than prestige
text: DMO will be a results-based online university that sells competence rather than prestige
quote: The most important fact about DMO is that students pay for results, not services. Therefore, a degree from DMO must be proof of competence. DMO does not sell prestige; it sells competence

claim: Organizations that sell results have well-defined objectives enabling good knowledge management
text: Organizations that sell results have well-defined objectives enabling good knowledge management
quote: Knowledge-management is possible when the organization in question has definite objectives, and when it does not have definite objectives, knowledge-management is as difficult as those objectives are vague

claim: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management to maintain inefficiencies
text: Service organizations depend on poor knowledge management to maintain inefficiencies
quote: When people within a given organization have an incentive to block communications within it, information tends to be blocked, and people within service organizations tend to have such incentives

claim: Education must be digitized whenever possible for efficiency and cost reduction
text: Education must be digitized whenever possible for efficiency and cost reduction
quote: when education can be digitized, it must be digitized... since doing so saves time and money and makes it easy for purchase custom-made education from the best instructors at the lowest possible price

claim: At DMO, instructors are paid directly by students based on performance, not by the institution
text: At DMO, instructors are paid directly by students based on performance, not by the institution
quote: students must negotiate prices directly with instructors, and payments must go straight to the instructor. The instructor will give a percentage of his earnings to DMO in exchange for use of the platform, business volume, credibility, instructional materials, and the like

claim: DMO will use independent examination-based accreditation rather than instructor grading
text: DMO will use independent examination-based accreditation rather than instructor grading
quote: At DMO, instructors do not issue grades. There are no grades. There are accreditations. Accreditations are attained by taking examinations. These examinations are graded anonymously (by computer, whenever possible). They are designed and administered by independent third parties

claim: DMO will convert liberal arts students to STEM through 'lite' science degrees
text: DMO will convert liberal arts students to STEM through 'lite' science degrees
quote: Its primary solution will be to offer lite science degrees: lite-physics, lite-math; math for computer scientists; lite biology. In this way, DMO gets people out of the doldrums of the liberal arts and into STEM

claim: DMO will be non-discriminatory and service all students unlike traditional universities
text: DMO will be non-discriminatory and service all students unlike traditional universities
quote: DMO has the first business model. Other universities have the second... If universities really sold instruction—in other words, if they made their money by seeing to it that people left them more competent than they came to them---they would want as many customers as possible

claim: DMO can offer multiple degree levels because individual courses have guaranteed meaning
text: DMO can offer multiple degree levels because individual courses have guaranteed meaning
quote: the greater the guarantee that a given course has meaning, and the greater the degree of specificity as to what meaning is, the fewer courses a student will have to take in order for that student to be recognized as having merit

claim: Students must be able to test out of courses to ensure instructors provide value rather than gatekeeping
text: Students must be able to test out of courses to ensure instructors provide value rather than gatekeeping
quote: DMO always offers students the ability to 'test out.' In other words, a student can get a given accreditation just by passing the examination in question: no time need be spent 'in class.'... As long as students have the option of testing out, it is guaranteed that students only pay instructors for actual instruction

claim: The inverted payment pyramid at DMO creates lean and functional operations
text: The inverted payment pyramid at DMO creates lean and functional operations
quote: At a conventional university, the money flows down. Students pay the university; the university pays instructors. The result: expensive and bad education. At DMO, the money flows up

claim: DMO will eliminate disciplines without practical value or objective assessment
text: DMO will eliminate disciplines without practical value or objective assessment
quote: Disciplines that have no practical value should either be jettisoned or modified so to have practical value... Disciplines that do not admit of objective assessments should either be jettisoned or modified so to admit of such assessments

claim: Student evaluations should be minimized in favor of performance-based instructor assessment
text: Student evaluations should be minimized in favor of performance-based instructor assessment
quote: The use of student evaluations should be minimized or eliminated. Student input should concern professionalism of instructor. The instructor's merit should be determined by student-performance, not by opinion or sentiment

claim: DMO hiring will be based solely on proven success with student outcomes
text: DMO hiring will be based solely on proven success with student outcomes
quote: Hirings are to be made exclusively on proven or probable success helping students pass accreditation exams. Therefore, publications are irrelevant to hiring decision, and so are letters of reference

claim: Existing universities cannot and should not be reformed
text: Existing universities cannot and should not be reformed
quote: There is little hope of reforming unviersities. They don't want to be reformed, and they don't stand to gain by being reformed

claim: Universities depend on inefficiency and poor knowledge management for their business model
text: Universities depend on inefficiency and poor knowledge management for their business model
quote: universities depend for their very existences on poor knowledge management... Universities fall into this category. They do provide some legitimate services, but these only account for a fraction of their revenue, the rest coming from overpriced ancillary services

claim: Universities have vague and incoherent objectives that prevent effective knowledge management
text: Universities have vague and incoherent objectives that prevent effective knowledge management
quote: Their objectives are therefore vague and incoherent, and it is correspondingly unclear what kind of information university-employees should make one another aware of

claim: The solution is creating new results-based educational services rather than reforming universities
text: The solution is creating new results-based educational services rather than reforming universities
quote: The right way to provide the public with better instruction is to create a new kind of educational service that is results-based and whose revenue is hewed to its pedagogical efficacy
